item.title: Increasing Bandwidth By Pair Bonding
item.description: When your T1 line starts reaching its bandwidth limit, upgrading to a DS3 line might seem like the next step, but it comes with challenges. DS3 often requires fiber optic cable instead of the copper used for T1, and the cost difference is significant. A simpler solution for a moderate bandwidth boost is adding another T1 line and using “pair bonding.” This technique combines two lines into one, effectively doubling your bandwidth to 3 Mbps.

item.title: Differences Between Fiber and EoC
item.description: Many businesses are analyzing if switching to fiber optic services is worthwhile due to limitations with their current internet and private line bandwidth. However, there’s now an additional choice: Ethernet over Copper (EoC). You might be surprised to learn that EoC’s bandwidth and affordability put it in a similar league as fiber optics. The traditional fiber optic service relies on the SONET (Synchronous Optical NETwork) standard, created by the telephone industry.

item.title: Do You Need Bandwidth on Demand?
item.description: By: John Shepler When subscribing to bandwidth, you’re usually expected to understand your network’s needs and pick the optimal service. But what if your needs are unclear or fluctuate? What about transitioning from in-house IT to cloud-based services? What are the consequences of an incorrect choice? Traditional Bandwidth Services Fall Short Conventional line contracts offer fixed bandwidth for a predetermined period, like a DS3 connection providing 45 Mbps constantly. While this guarantees consistent speed, you pay even when it’s idle.

item.title: How MPLS Network Bursting Provides Flexibility
item.description: The standard method of ordering bandwidth for last-mile connections or MPLS networks involves committing to a specific rate or line speed. For instance, a T1 line provides a constant 1.5 Mbps, while a 10 Mbps Ethernet service delivers precisely that speed. In multi-tenant networks like MPLS VPNs, you purchase a committed information rate representing the maximum speed your connection will achieve. However, what happens if business needs change or your initial estimate is inaccurate?
